subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}

{{liushu|p}} – a flagpole. Based on archaeological evidence, the middle box has been interpreted as a drum ({{zh-l|*建鼓}}). This flagpole with a drum was placed in the center of a field to gather people and to detect the direction of the wind. In addition, the pronunciation of {{och-l|中}} is reminiscent of the beating of a drum.

''[[w:Shuowen|Shuowen]]'' interprets the character as a vertical stroke {{zh-l|*丨}} passing through the center of {{zh-l|*口}}, indicating the center.

It has also been interpreted as an arrow in the center of a target.

subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
“Middle; centre” (Pronunciation 1) > “to hit the centre; to attain” (Pronunciation 2).

From {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*t/duŋ}}. Cognate with {{cog|bo|གཞུང||middle, center}}.

Related to:
* {{och-l|衷|middle; inner garment; inner feelings}};
* {{och-l|仲|second (of the brothers or months)}}.
